frameDefinitions: This frame describes food and meal preparation.
One Part of a larger Whole has been mentioned, is inferrable, or is available in the discourse setting and the previously unmentioned part, the Rest, is now mentioned.
An Agent displays a Characteristic of a Standard in his or her own way of behaving.
A Claimant asserts his or her right to possession of a piece of Property (either real, such as land, or private).
An Agent produces a Forgery, an entity that they intend to pass off as a particular (instance of)  a Standard.
A Creator  produces a physical object which is to serve as a Representation of an actual or imagined entity or event, the Represented.
frameExamples: Caitlin <t>baked</t> some cookies from the pre-packaged dough.
The lenses , like the <t><fex name='Rest'>rest</fex></t> of the exoskeleton, are made of calcite.
I guessed he was trying to <t>imitate</t> the movements of a skier
The King <t>claims</t> this land and surrounding waters.
So who was it that <t>faked</t> the photo 'showing' Jane Fonda and John Kerry with the Vietcong?
Epstein saw the machine-man and <t>carved</t> him in shiny metal.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Cook</fen>  prepares the <fen>Produced_food</fen>.
The <fen>Produced_food</fen> is the result of a <fen>Cook</fen>'s efforts.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the cooking creation occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the cooking creation occurs.
A <fen>Part</fen> of a larger <fen>Whole</fen> that has been mentioned in prior discourse or is available in the discourse setting.
The previously unmentioned part of the <fen>Whole</fen>.
The larger entitiy or group that is fully made up of the <fen>Part</fen> and the <fen>Rest</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person that borrows a <fen>Characteristic</fen> behavior from a <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Characteristic</fen> is a behavior or property that the <fen>Standard</fen> possesses and which the <fen>Agent</fen> adopts in his or her own behavior.
The <fen>Standard</fen> is the entity that exhibits a certain <fen>Characteristic</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> models their own behavior on.
The time at which the imitation occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> imitates some entity which acts as a <fen>Standard</fen>.
The Claimant asserts rights or priviliges, typically ownership, over some Property.
The <fen>Property</fen> is declared to be under the ownership of the <fen>Claimant</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the person that creates a Forgery with the intent of passing it off as (an instance of) the <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Forgery</fen> is the product that the <fen>Agent</fen> creates with the intent of passing it off as (an instance of) the <fen>Standard</fen>.
The <fen>Standard</fen> is the actually existing or imagined (kind of) thing that the <fen>Agent</fen> wants to pass the <fen>Forgery</fen> off as.
The time at which the forgery takes place.
The location in which the <fen>Agent</fen> makes a <fen>Forgery</fen>.
An individual or individuals that bring the <fen>Representation</fen> into existence.
The entity--which may be a thing, an action or a state--that is represented by the <fen>Representation</fen>.
The time at which a <fen>Representation</fen> is created.
The location in which the artist produces the representation.
listRoleExamples: Drew baked an apple pie <fex>at six int he morning</fex>.
Drew prepared the soup <fex> in the kitchen</fex>.
the GP had stipulated counselling as a complement <fex>to medication</fex>
You should try to persuade the <fex>rest</fex> of the family to do so whatever their personal opinions
Mimic Snotlings do n't really think for themselves, <fex>they</fex> merely mimic the actions of Orcs and Goblins around them.
The singer says Gwen has copied <fex>her</fex> in many different ways.
The king ordered <fex>the envoy</fex> to claim the land accross the river.
I claim <fex>this forest and environs</fex> in the name of the Queen.
Since <fex>Frans</fex> photographed them ten years ago the population has increased.
When Nadar photographed <fex>her</fex>, Desbordes-Valmore was sixty-eight.
I drew him <fex>at work</fex> a bunch of times, mainly for the amusement of the staff.
